metadata.title: Dynamic mechanical properties of oil palm nano filler/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Dynamic mechanical properties of oil palm nano filler/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2016.07.059 0950-0618/ 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: naheedchem@gmail.com (N. Saba).
N. Saba a,⇑, M.T. Paridah a, K. Abdan b, N.A. Ibrahim c a Laboratory of Biocomposite Technology, Institute of Tropical Forestry and Forest Products (INTROP), Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 UPM Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia bDepartment of Biological and Agricultural Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University Putra Malaysia, 43400 UPM Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia cDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University Putra Malaysia, 43400 UPM Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia
h i g h l i g h t s
Effect of oil palm nano filler on DMA of epoxy hybrid nanocomposites were made. Tg and shapes of cole-cole plot of kenaf/epoxy and hybrid nanocomposites evaluated. Comparative DMA study of oil palm nano filler, MMT and OMMT hybrid nanocomposites. Considerable improvement in dynamic properties observed for nano OPEFB hybrid.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 3 June 2016 Received in revised form 22 June 2016 Accepted 15 July 2016
Keywords: Epoxy Oil palm nano filler Kenaf fibers Nanoclay Dynamic mechanical properties Glass transition temperature
a b s t r a c t
Epoxy based hybrid nanocomposites was prepared by dispersing the different nano fillers -nano oil palm empty fruit bunch (OPEFB) filler, MMT, and OMMT at 3% loading through high speed mechanical stirrer followed by hand lay-up technique. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA), in terms of storage modulus (E0), loss modulus (E00), Tan delta (d) and glass transition temperature (Tg) as a function of temperature were carried out. Overall results indicated that E0 , E00 and Tg increased considerably by incorporating nano OPEFB filler, MMT and OMMT nanoclay into the kenaf/epoxy composites. Nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites displayed comparable properties to MMT/kenaf/epoxy but less than OMMT/ kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites.
2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Reinforcements of natural fibers for fabricating polymer composites and hybrid composites are established around early 1900 s [1,2,3]. Natural fibers including kenaf and oil palm empty fruit bunch (OPEFB) fibers, exhibit a number of advantages that required for making polymer green composites and nanocomposites, along with certain disadvantages including, poor wettability, incompatibility with some polymeric matrices, and high moisture adsorption [4,5]. Malaysia alone produces 6.93 million tons of OPEFB cellulosic bio-wastes from oil palmmill after stripping fruits from the oil palm fresh fruit bunch (OPFB), besides oil palm fronds, oil palm trunks [6,7]. OPEFB has great potential to yield up to 73% OPEFB fibers, by water retting process, which is quite economical and safer to use [8,9].
Kenaf fibers are gratifying increasingly widespread throughout the world and are commercially cultivated in more than 20 countries, as a significant and promising reinforcing materials, alternatives to glass fibers, owing to its high specific mechanical properties and low density [2]. Research study explored that the incorporation of nano filler as doping agent noticeably reduces the limitations of polymer and polymer composites by improving the matrix/fibers interaction [10,1]. A variety of synthesis methods for nano filler such as chemical, biological and mechanical techniques are known. Currently nano filler either from natural or synthetic source displayed great interest in comparison with bulk counterparts [10].
The utilization of cellulosic and agricultural wastes as filler in polymer composites industries receives greater attention. Sugarcane bagasse as filler in recycled polyethylene [11], rice husk reinforced in polyester [12], coconut shell reinforced in polyethylene [13], bio-waste wood apple and coconut shell particulate reinforced in epoxy [14], tea mill waste fibers (TMWF) in
polypropylene (PP) and high density polyethylene (HDPE) [15], mixtures of household waste of mate-tea and eucalypt particles filled polypropylene [16], sawdust and rice husk flour in polyethylene [17], carbon black and activated carbon (AC) derived from OPEFB fibers, bamboo stem, coconut shell [18,19] and oil palm ash (OPA) from the combustion process of OPEFB biomass at the oil mills [20,21], currently receiving higher attention in the polymer composites industries.
Nanocomposites are the indispensable engineering nanomaterials due to their unique properties and multi-functionality as compared with traditional composites [22,23]. Polymer nanocomposites derived from wastes materials and nanoclay such as a montmorillonite (MMT) or synthetic clay (layered double hydroxide) are the only way to replace the existing costly nano filler [3]. MMT has been extensively used from past 50 years, after being first labelled inmontmorillonmineral in department of Vienne (France), owing to its high-aspect ratio, swelling nature, dispersion capability and plate morphology [24,25]. However MMT display certain limitation owing to its hydrophilic nature [3]. The lower compatibility of MMT, can be overcome by typically modifying with ammonium or phosphonium salts, resulting the formation of ‘‘organoclay or organically modified nanoclays (OMMT)” [26]. Until now many research studies were conveyed involving natural fiber hybridization with polymer having dispersed MMT, and OMMT nanoclay for varied advanced applications.
DMA is the most indispensable, sensitive and effective thermomechanical technique for determining the viscoelastic properties of polymer composite materials [23,27]. Storage modulus (E0) typically related to the Young’s modulus, and determines the ‘‘stiffness” and load bearing capability of the composite materials [7]. Dynamic loss modulus (E00) defines a viscous response of the materials [28]. Mechanical damping parameter or Tan delta (Tan d), of the composites materials are obtained from Tan d = E00/E0 and expressed as a dimensionless number [23]. Tan d specifies the elastic, viscous and impact properties of a materials [29]. It has been reviewed that the damping factor of the polymer is much greater than fibers, as the polymers possess higher viscosity and lowered elasticity [5]. The Tg defines the temperature range where a thermosetting polymer changes from a ‘‘glassy”, hard or rigid state to a more pliable, compliant or ‘‘rubbery” state [23]. Cole-cole plot or wicket plot, describes the structural changes and phases (homogeneous, heterogeneous) occurred by the addition of fibers or filler in the cross linked polymeric system [30,7].
In previous research work, we developed nano filler from OPEFB fibers by using cryogenizer and high energy ball milling (HEBM) techniques [6]. Current paper evaluates the effect of developed nano OPEFB filler on the dynamic mechanical properties of locally available Malaysian kenaf bast fibers reinforced epoxy composites. It is evident from literature review that no work has been yet reported on the addition of nano OPEFB filler to improve the dynamic properties (in terms of storage modulus, loss modulus, damping factor, Tg) of kenaf/epoxy composites. The obtained results are also compared with MMT/kenaf/epoxy and OMMT/ kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. The success of this research findings will provide promising green environmentally sound nano filler from bio-wastes which distract the prevailing flow of using expensive nano filler like carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene oxide and inorganic metal oxides in the polymer composites industry.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
The OPEFB fiber was obtained from MPOB, Bangi-Selangor, Malaysia. The kenaf non-woven mat was obtained from Innovative
Pultrusion Sdn, Bhd, Malaysia. The chemical composition, mechanical and physical properties of OPEFB fiber and kenaf fiber are tabulated in Table 1 [22].
Montmorillonite (MMT) and organically modified montmorillonite (OMMT) nanoclay were procured from Zarm scientific & Supplies Sdn., Bhd, Malaysia. Chemically MMT nanoclay is a hydrated sodium calcium aluminium magnesium silicate hydroxide (Na, Ca)0.33 (Al, Mg)2(Si4O10)(OH)2 nH2O. The MMT powder has surface area of 250 m2/g with the pH 3–4. OMMT were the nanoclay Nanomer I.31PS, contains 0.5–5 wt.% aminopropyltriethoxysilane, 15–35 wt.% octadecylamine as montmorillonite clay base material. It is white to off white powder having bulk density 200–500 kg/m3. The epoxy resin D.E.R 331 used in this study is a clear liquid resin based on diglycidyl ether of bisphenol A (DGEBA), obtained from Dow Chemical Pacific Singapore, Singapore. The curing agent, epoxy hardener Jointmine 905-3S is a clear and transparent color liquid. It is a modified cycloaliphatic amine, supplied by Epochemie International Pte Ltd., Singapore. Silicone spray used in this study is procured from Dow Chemical Pacific Singapore, Singapore. Teflon sheets are procured from NR Medicare Sdn. Bhd., Selangor, Malaysia. The purchased chemicals were directly used without any further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of composites
sections.text: Obtained kenaf non-woven mat were first pressed by hot press for 8 min at 40 C. Two pressed non-woven kenaf mats having total weight of 162.57 g, are used in this research study for the fabrication of both kenaf/epoxy composites and all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. In the fabrication of hybrid nanocomposites, the prior dried nano fillers (OPEFB, MMT, OMMT) are uniformly dispersed at 3% (by weight) loading in epoxy resin through high speed mechanical stirrer at room temperature for 60 min. This was followed by mixing of hardener and pouring in the pre-covered mould with Teflon sheet in alternate layering of nano filler-epoxy system and two kenaf pressed mats. After 24 h, at room temperature, the composite was then detached carefully from the steel mould. The same procedure was carried out for the fabrication of rest of all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. Kenaf/epoxy composites are fabricated to make comparative study by the hand lay-up technique, with the only exception that no nano fillers have been incorporated during fabrication.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text:
DMA was executed according to ASTM D4065-01 to determine the viscoelastic behavior (E0, E00, Tan d) of kenaf/epoxy composites and nano filler filled (nano OPEFB, MMT, OMMT nanoclay) kenaf/ epoxy hybrid nanocomposites as a function of temperature. DMA test was performed using TA (DMA Q 800) instrument, operating in a three-point bending mode at an oscillation frequency of 1 Hz under controlled amplitude. The temperature was ramped from 30 C to 200 C, under controlled sinusoidal strain with a heating
rate of 5 C/min. The samples were in dimension of 60 12.5 3 mm3. The fabricated kenaf/epoxy composites, nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites and DMA instrument are displayed in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 3. Result and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Storage modulus (E0)
Fig. 2 illustrates the effect of nano filler (nano OPEFB, MMT, OMMT) loading on the storage modulus (E0) of kenaf/epoxy composites. On investigating, the variations of E0 with temperature of kenaf/epoxy composites, it is evident that E0 was found to be decreased with temperature in all cases. The obtained E0 graph are also in agreement with the E0 graph obtained in the case of poly lactic acid (PLA) based hybrid nanocomposites with inorganic nano filler and cellulose fibers [31]. It’s clear from the Fig. 2, that the E0 tends to become broader in glassy region, as the components are in close, tightly packed and in frozen state resulting high storage modulus value below Tg. Moreover, the E0 curves suffer an intense drop around 75–100 C indicating glass/rubbery state transition. But when the temperature increases the composites components tend to show increased molecular mobility, hence, lose their tight packing arrangement, this then gradually decreases the E0 values in rubbery region. However no considerable changes in the rubbery
region were observed for kenaf/epoxy composites and in all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. The obtained results are similar with other research findings for silica nano particles/silver nanowires/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites [32]. The storage modulus curves also clearly depicts that the incorporation of nano filler in the kenaf/epoxy composites increases the E0 values considerably. This ascribed by the fact that addition of nano filler effectively alleviates the modulus mismatch between stiff kenaf fibers and epoxy matrix thus improve the interfacial bonding between fibers and matrix. Furthermore, the dynamic modulus curves of nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites displayed a comparable values to MMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites, but relatively better E0 properties with respect to kenaf/epoxy composites below Tg region. Interestingly, OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites displayed highest E0 values in both the glassy and rubbery region among all the kenaf/epoxy composites. The highest E0 value for OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites can be ascribed by the facts that, the addition of layered OMMT nanoclay restrict the movements of the epoxy polymer chains as they get intercalated in between the phyllosilicate layers of OMMT nanoclay. Thus on applying sinusoidal dynamic force to the highly stiffed OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposite, the stress transfer is quite remarkable. The statements are also in line with other research findings [33]. The obtained higher E0 values for all
kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites also reflects their relatively high mechanical properties, compared to kenaf/epoxy composites.
3.2. Loss modulus (E00)
The compiled DMA curves of loss modulus (E00) versus temperature of kenaf/epoxy composites and filler filled (nano OPEFB, MMT, OMMTnanoclay) kenaf/epoxyhybridnanocomposites are displayed in Fig. 3. From lossmodulus plot it is apparent that lossmodulus also displays very similar trend with the storage modulus, showing improvements by the addition of nano OPEFB filler in kenaf/epoxy composites. A similar loss modulus graph are observed for glass and ramie fibers reinforced in polyester [34]. Furthermore, all loss modulus curves reach a maximum values for maximum dissipation of mechanical energy and decreases for higher temperatures, as a result of the free movement of the polymer chains. It is also clearly evident from Fig. 3, that the incorporation of nano OPEFB, MMT and OMMT nanoclay causes the broadening of the loss modulus peak, due to the increase in chain segments. Interestingly, the E00 value peak height was much higher for all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites as compared to kenaf/epoxy composites; due to increase in internal friction that enhances the dissipation of energy. Thus kenaf/epoxy composites shows the lowered E00 peak height whereas, the OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites displays thehigher E00 peakheight. The E00 value in transition regionwasmuch higher for OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites, followed by MMT/kenaf/epoxy and nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. However, both the MMT and OMMT filled kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites displayed comparatively higher dynamic loss modulus values with relative to nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites as the polar and nonpolar groups of nanoclay enhanced the interfacial interaction between the reactants and thus results improvement in E00 value. Similar arguments were also reported in literature [33]. Above Tg all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites show higher value of E00 compared to kenaf/epoxy composites. The highest E00 max peak was observed for OMMT/ kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites followed by MMT and nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. Fig. 3 illustrates highest E00 peak height of OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites, indicating the possibilities of its higher tensile properties and lower in kenaf/epoxy composites among all composites [22]. Moreover, the incorporation of stiff filler (nano OPEFB) and layered phyllosilicate minerals (MMT, OMMT) into the kenaf/epoxy composites also improved the complex modulus (E*) of the resulting respective kenaf/epoxyhybridnanocomposites compared tokenaf/epoxycomposites. It canbeexplainedonaccount of increase inboth the storage (E0) and loss (E00)modulus valueswith the incorporationof nanofiller [35].

sections.heading: 3.3. Damping factor (Tan d)
sections.text: Fig. 4 elucidates Tan d of kenaf/epoxy composites and nano filler filled (nano OPEFB, MMT, OMMT nanoclay) kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. The kenaf/epoxy composites displayed the highest damping factor and the OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites shows the lowest among all. It is also observed from Fig. 4, that damping factor increases with increase in temperature and it reaches maximum level in the transition region, followed by decrease in rubbery region for all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites and kenaf/epoxy composites. The damping factor graph evidently shows that all composites possess lowest values below Tg, due to frozen chain segments at this stage; resulting greater degree of molecular mobility at higher Tan d peak values. Interestingly, the nano OPEFB incorporation in kenaf/epoxy composites shows improved damping properties with respect to kenaf/epoxy composites. The incorporation of stiffer and harder nano OPEFB filler into the epoxy matrix restrains the segment mobility of the matrix molecules, resulting higher increment in E0 values compared with E00 values for the nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. Thus the addition of nano OPEFB filler decreases the Tan d for both, before and after the glass transition region, since the mechanical loss to overcome inter friction between molecular chains also gets reduced. The result are also in agreement with other research findings [5,35]. Additionally, it also been observed that the Tan d peak was associated with both the Tg and crosslinking density. From the Fig. 4, it is apparent that the Tan d peak became broader for all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites compared with kenaf/epoxy composites. A wider peak indicated a more time for relaxation of molecules due to lower polymeric chains movement, signifying the formation of higher crosslinking density for all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites, mainly due to better interfacial interaction. Obtained results are also in line with other research findings [33,36].

sections.heading: 3.4. Glass transition temperatures (Tg)
sections.text:
The Tg was derived from the onsets of the strident drop in Tan d curve or from the peak position of Tan d. Research study established that Tg values achieved from the E00 were more convincing and realistic with relative to the values obtained from damping factor [28,23]. Table 2 illustrates the peak height of Tan d curve and Tg values from the Tan d and the E00 values. From Table 2, Tg obtained from E00 found to be lower than that of Tan d curves, also been reviewed by other researchers [37,38]. From the Table 2, it is evident that the kenaf/epoxy composites has comparatively lower Tg values obtained from both E00 and Tan d peak among all kenaf/ epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. This can well be explained by the reinforcing effect of the nano particles leading to increased stiffness of kenaf/epoxy composites. The shifts in the Tg of the kenaf/ epoxy composites with the addition of nano filler indicate that added nano filler acts as inhibitors in segmental motion of the polymeric chain resulting from the nano filler/matrix interaction. Similar dynamic Tg properties are also conveyed by researchers
for organoclay/woven carbon fiber (CF)/compatibilized polypropylene (PPc) nanocomposites [36].
Thus the considerable increases in Tg and decrease in the Tan d peak height of all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites clearly revealed that the molecular mobility of epoxy matrix has decreased considerably with respect to its movement in the kenaf/epoxy composites. Similar results were also reported by other researchers [39].

sections.heading: 3.5. Cole-Cole plot
sections.text: Cole-cole plot is the highly profound and valuable tool to interpret the relationship between loss modulus (E00) with storage modulus (E0) [40,41]. A smooth, semicircular arc of the plotted curves proposed homogenous polymeric system [30]. Moreover, imperfect or irregular shape signifies the interface effects and nonhomogeneous dispersion or phase heterogeneity in the polymeric system [28,42]. Fig. 5 displayed the cole–cole plot where the loss modulus data are plotted as a function of storage modulus for all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites and kenaf/epoxy composites. The cole-cole curve of kenaf/epoxy composites displays relatively less heterogeneity in the epoxy, indicating poor interfacial bonding between kenaf fibers and epoxy matrix. The cole-cole plot also evidently shows the imperfect semicircle resembling the more heterogeneity among all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites, associated with greater differences in the relaxation process associated with incorporated nano fillers (nano OPEFB, MMT, OMMT). The imperfect semicircular curve of all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites relatively displayed better fiber/matrix interfacial bonding. The results are in agreement with other research findings involving basalt fibers and aramid fibers reinforced phenolic composites [38]. The obtained results also concise with other findings where hybrid composites involving ramie and glass fibers in the unsaturated polyester displayed the similar cole-cole plotting [34]. Thus the incorporation of nano filler (nano OPEFB, MMT, OMMT) to the kenaf/epoxy composites greatly affects the shapes of cole-cole plot and thereby influencing their dynamic mechanical properties with function to temperature.

sections.heading: 4. Potential applications
sections.text:
The fabricated nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites possess the satisfactory dynamic mechanical properties and hence it can replace the traditional constructional materials such as ceramic bricks, cement, aggregates, steel, aluminium, wood, cladding and partitioning materials in order to developed sustainable green
buildings. The inclusion of this material in a construction project by replacing conventional and expensive materials considerably results cost effective structural building materials, due to their lower material cost, fabrication cost, constructional cost and minimal repairing costs.
The combination of high storage modulus and low damping factor displays better specific strength and modulus, hence its applications can also be extended to design connecting bridges, bridges decks, stairs, railing and outdoor decking, doors, doors frames and plumbing components on account of its lower weights and lower damping properties compared with expensive wooden blogs. Its applications can also be extended in many low stress applications areas such as housing sectors, windmill blades, industrial drive shafts, highway bridges support beams and paper making rollers. Moreover it can also emerge as an alternate and promising material to replace costly steel, aluminium, stones, concrete and timber wood in Malaysia.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
From the analysis, it has been found that the addition of nano OPEFB, MMT and OMMT nanoclay, greatly changes the dynamic properties of the kenaf/epoxy composites. Incorporation of nano OPEFB filler in kenaf/epoxy composites enhanced the storage modulus (E0) and loss modulus values of kenaf/epoxy composites. The improvement can be ascribed owing to hardness and stiffness of the incorporated nano OPEFB filler. Nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposite also display noticeable decrease in damping factor compared with kenaf/epoxy composites. The decrease in damping factor can be ascribed on account of restriction imparted by the nano OPEFB filler to the free segmental movement of epoxy molecular chain and improved interfacial bonding between kenaf fibers and epoxy matrix. Tg values obtained from Tan d peak and loss modulus (E00) values shows a noticeable improvement in all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. Interestingly, the marked increase in the dynamic mechanical properties of nano OPEFB/ kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites was found to be comparable with MMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites and relatively lesser with respect to OMMT/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. Drawn cole–cole plot evidently shows an imperfect semicircular shape indicating heterogeneity of the system as well as good fiber/ matrix bonding for all kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites.
The use of nano OPEFB filler thus can generate promising and innovative platform to other expensive and environmentally high impact filler. Overall, from the results we concluded that the hybridization results eco-friendly nanocomposites, possessing satisfactory dynamic modulus and damping properties. The enhanced properties of the nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites indicates a high possibility in advanced light weight structural applications such as aircrafts, buildings, bridges, boats, reservoirs and pressure vessels where renewable resource and high performance are required.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The authors extend their gratitude to the Universiti Putra Malaysia, Malaysia for supporting this research finding throughout through Putra Grant, Vot No. 9420700.

Natural fibers including kenaf and oil palm empty fruit bunch (OPEFB) fibers, exhibit a number of advantages that required for making polymer green composites and nanocomposites, along with certain disadvantages including, poor wettability, incompatibility with some polymeric matrices, and high moisture adsorption [4,5].

Kenaf fibers are gratifying increasingly widespread throughout the world and are commercially cultivated in more than 20 countries, as a significant and promising reinforcing materials, alternatives to glass fibers, owing to its high specific mechanical properties and low density [2].

Nanocomposites are the indispensable engineering nanomaterials due to their unique properties and multi-functionality as compared with traditional composites [22,23].

Polymer nanocomposites derived from wastes materials and nanoclay such as a montmorillonite (MMT) or synthetic clay (layered double hydroxide) are the only way to replace the existing costly nano filler [3].

MMT has been extensively used from past 50 years, after being first labelled inmontmorillonmineral in department of Vienne (France), owing to its high-aspect ratio, swelling nature, dispersion capability and plate morphology [24,25].

MMT has been extensively used from past 50 years, after being first labelled inmontmorillonmineral in department of Vienne (France), owing to its high-aspect ratio, swelling nature, dispersion capability and plate morphology [24,25].
However MMT display certain limitation owing to its hydrophilic nature [3].
The lower compatibility of MMT, can be overcome by typically modifying with ammonium or phosphonium salts, resulting the formation of ‘‘organoclay or organically modified nanoclays (OMMT)” [26].
DMA is the most indispensable, sensitive and effective thermomechanical technique for determining the viscoelastic properties of polymer composite materials [23,27].
DMA is the most indispensable, sensitive and effective thermomechanical technique for determining the viscoelastic properties of polymer composite materials [23,27].
Storage modulus (E0) typically related to the Young’s modulus, and determines the ‘‘stiffness” and load bearing capability of the composite materials [7].
Dynamic loss modulus (E00) defines a viscous response of the materials [28].
Mechanical damping parameter or Tan delta (Tan d), of the composites materials are obtained from Tan d = E00/E0 and expressed as a dimensionless number [23].
Tan d specifies the elastic, viscous and impact properties of a materials [29].
It has been reviewed that the damping factor of the polymer is much greater than fibers, as the polymers possess higher viscosity and lowered elasticity [5].
The Tg defines the temperature range where a thermosetting polymer changes from a ‘‘glassy”, hard or rigid state to a more pliable, compliant or ‘‘rubbery” state [23].
Cole-cole plot or wicket plot, describes the structural changes and phases (homogeneous, heterogeneous) occurred by the addition of fibers or filler in the cross linked polymeric system [30,7].

metadata.abstractText: Epoxy based hybrid nanocomposites was prepared by dispersing the different nano fillers -nano oil palm empty fruit bunch (OPEFB) filler, MMT, and OMMT at 3% loading through high speed mechanical stirrer followed by hand lay-up technique. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA), in terms of storage modulus (E0), loss modulus (E00), Tan delta (d) and glass transition temperature (Tg) as a function of temperature were carried out. Overall results indicated that E0 , E00 and Tg increased considerably by incorporating nano OPEFB filler, MMT and OMMT nanoclay into the kenaf/epoxy composites. Nano OPEFB/kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites displayed comparable properties to MMT/kenaf/epoxy but less than OMMT/ kenaf/epoxy hybrid nanocomposites. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
